												Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a follow up to the original Counter-Strike game. This game was released in 2004, so almost eleven years ago. Condition Zero uses the Half-Life engine. What we have here is a CS game which includes a single player mission pack. When it comes to playing Counter-Strike, I am more or less a newb at it. This game gave me the perfect opportunity to learn the guns, maps and mission types without the pressure of feeling like you are letting your team down by sucking. The campaign took me about four hours to complete, but this was only on Normal mode, you can go back and replay the missions on a higher difficulty to eventually work your way up to playing online. I also found the squad management system to be a nice little feature which isn't seen in other CS games, at the start of each mission, you can choose which squad members to take with you on the mission, each of the team members have their positive and negative stats so you can really get stuck in with min-maxing them. You start out with three members and you work you way up to having a full blown squad of about eight men. On each of the missions you also have to complete specific challenges, these can be goals set around killing a certain amount of people, winning the match in less than ninety seconds, rescuing a specific amount of hostages etc etc. This added a little variety of play, especially the challenges where you have to use a certain weapon in order to complete them. This allowed you to learn how to use other guns effectively rather than sticking with your tried and tested Rifle and Deagle. While the graphics do not come close to looking like games we have in the current day, the game still does look nice. I wasn't put off by the dated graphics one bit; I guess that just shows how good the Half Life engine actually is!  The difficulty levels completely rely on how hard you want to make it. I started out on Normal mode just to get to grips with the game as I am newb like that; but you can work all the way up to playing as if you are in a match online and have the brutally hard experience if you want to. Easy mode is complete walk in the park though, enemies can be standing in front of you for about three seconds before they realize they should shoot you, and even then they spray bullets randomly all around you without actually hitting, so I wouldn't recommend you start out on Easy mode. Like I said, the campaign took me about four hours to complete, but there are two or three more difficulty levels to try out, and I can see this adding a lot of variety into the game play, so I can easily see the single player alone taking about twelve hours to complete it fully on all difficulties. I found no technical issues what so ever while playing, I would assume all the bugs and niggles would of been ironed out years ago.. In conclusion I can easily recommend Counter-Strike: Condition Zero for anyone looking to get into the FPS or CS scene, it will easily give you a worthwhile experience, giving you the opportunity to learn all of the CS maps, guns and game modes in a pressure free environment. If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Update: Currently at frustrating point where the Terrorist AI is almost cheating and the Counter-Terrorist AI is braindead.Then I tried out the multiplayer for a bit. Not long enough for me to actually say anything about it, but from my limited experience it felt like CS:S but different. 												      Counter Strike Condition Zero is an odd one. Caught in between CS 1.6 and Source, it came very close to CS: Source's release, and was brushed aside. At the time, it graphics were outdated, and its single player content was lacking. Today, the single player content is just as lackluster. The regular campaign is literally offline bots with some slight customization. It's bland, boring, and the AI is pretty terrible. There's also the "Deleted Scenes", which is actually an entirely other game. It's a single player CS Campaign that plays nothing like Counter Strike. It feels more like a fast-paced Arcade shooter. It's plagued with poor map design, cheesey plot that desperately wanted to blend with games like Halo at the time, and gimmicky spy gadgets that while intriguing at first, are poorly executed.     Where Condition Zero does shine is its multiplayer. It's graphics are dated but timeless. It feels like an updated CS 1.6 in visuals, and plays in a way thats really unique to Condition Zero. Ammunition is expensive and money is tight, so you really have to watch your shots in this game. It still has a very large playerbase, and holds up much better than the classic 1.6    While Condition Zero failed to capture a single player Counter Strike expirience, it did create a pretty fun Multiplayer that's still fun to hop on today. It's by no means a masterpiece, but it isn't a bad game. If the CS Anthology pack ever goes on sale, I'd say pick it up and try it out. But on its own, I'd say it's a pass.

												Synopsis:With its extensive Tour of Duty campaign, a near-limitless number of skirmish modes, updates and new content for Counter-Strike's award-winning multiplayer game play, plus over 12 bonus single player missions, Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a tremendous offering of single and multiplayer content. My thoughts regarding Condition Zero are pretty much Identical to the original CS 1.6. This is basically due to both games sharing the same engine, with Condition Zero being different only in the texturing and meshing department. With CS 1.6 showing its age, Condition Zero might be a worth a squirt if your feeling nostalgic. Basically once the game Is bought you have to two installation options, Counter Strike Condition Zero and Counter Strike Condition Zero: Deleted Scenes.Counter Strike Condition Zero:This is essentially the CS 1.6 variant of the game which allows for traditional CS 1.6 style online gameplay and a somewhat enjoyable mini campaign which spans across most of the original maps, where objectives are the same as multiplayer however you can build a team for each map with bots of varying skills with more powerful bots costing more resource which you will unlock as you complete the maps. This single player should be avoided since it offers no real value and you are much better off playing on servers with real players.Counter Strike Condition Zero Deleted Scenes:This installation covers the actual single player campaign for Condition Zero. Each theater consists of you playing as a different counter terrorist unit: GIGN, GSG-9, SEAL Team 6, SAS and SpetsnazYou in turn fight againest a variety of different terrorist factions:Arctic Avengers, Elite Crew, Guerilla Warfare, Phoenix Connexion and Midwest Militia.I rather enjoyed the single player campaign since it deployed a large variety of maps and global locations ranging from fetid jungles to war ravaged cities. Most missions have a pre deployment briefing but these just offer simple intel and not much else. Most missions range from hostage rescue, bomb disarmament to assassinations. In most respects the campaign is somewhat reminiscent to Call of Duty MW which often puts you in the boots of a different soldier serving under a different army.In conclusion CS CZ is worth your time if you are a hardcore C.S 1.6 fan like myself. It is pretty much HD 1.6 with a enjoyable single player campaign.Final Score: 85/100

												The more polished, better looking cousin of Counter Strike, Condition Zero is the version of Counter Strike to not only play, but for developers to beat.  The addition of the much-required shield has an important balance factor; it counters the usage of the AWP.The hit detection is once again, superior to CSGO, much like the previous Counter Strike, and the aim for the weapons isn't cartoonishly exaggerated where you have weapons like the M249 and the shotgun being actually viable.Online play is head-and-heels above CSGO's.  In CSGO you feel like everythings a waste of time unless you're playing in competitive matches, while in CSCZ, and CS, pubs rule the game (like all classic multiplayer games).  I can't say how sweet it was when someone who was clearly a CSGO player who looks like he just started playing CSCZ, killed a team mate to defuse the bomb himself, and then got perma-banned by the moderator.  It was also the moment where I realized that the behaviors of players in CSCZ compared to CSGO are not just different, but the CSGO behavior is just ♥♥♥♥ing awful and counter-intuitive to team work.  You have people competing fo points to get a higher rank quicker so that they can unlock more skins, which they can trade/sell for a hugely over-priced margin (some skins being worth more than CSGO itself).I guess it just goes to show that if you're someone who actually wants to enjoy playing the game, CSCZ is the game for you.  CSGO is just another "competitive" game with nothing more to it than popularity, driven mostly by the market economy the game has created for itself, suffering the same fate as TF2 and Dota 2.I would recommend CSCZ over CSGO any day and not because it's what I used to play (since I have none, as I barely ever touched it for more than a few minutes back in the day), but because the balance, design, and overall aesthetic is just so much more satisfying and fun to experience compared to more modern online FPS games.

												Buried beneath the successes of Valve's blockbuster titles, Condition Zero is a hidden gem that boasts both singleplayer and multiplayer entertainment. The main reason you should consider this is for the Deleted Scenes section, which contains a variety of content not used by the base game. From a legitimate story mode (with rather cinematic and interesting moments) to fun new weapons (M60's and blowtorches, to name a few), it pretty much is worth the price of admission. The base game is decent as well, but it can be easily replicated by playing CS:S or Global Offensive with bots. Deleted Scenes features a story mode with, well, a story. 18 unconnected stories, sure, but the variety of locations ingame makes up for the lack of consistency.Overall, it's a fun diversion when you're yearning for another story-based game from Valve. At a price of 5-10 dollars, you're basically getting two high-quality games for the price of one. I would recommend it to Counter-Strike and Half-Life fans alike.

												Counter Strike Condition Zero is an interesting game to discuss not because of it's merits as a game but largely for it's history. It had a surprisingly troubled development and changed hands between 4 distinctive developers before finally becoming finished. The game was originally designed by Rogue, the developers behind Strife and American McGee's Alice. However the developer went out of buisiness so Valve instead gave it to Gearbox, who Valve had previously worked with on Opposing Force and Blue Shift. Much of the game is based around Gearbox's version, which focused on creating more impressive graphics and remaking many of the classic Counter Strike maps in better detail.However, the project changed hands again and the game was handed off to Ritual entertainment. The guys behind SiN. They remade the game as a pseudo singleplayer title before Valve decided to hand the game off to Turtlerock studios. Who would years later create Left 4 Dead. Who finished the game and completed it based on Gearbox's version. The content Ritual made would be released as the "Deleted scenes".The final game is very much inspired by Counter Strike 1.6. It plays very similarly albiet with nicer graphics and a very different art style. It was also the very first Counter Strike game to ship with bots by default. The game also contains a singleplayer separate from the Deleted Scenes, however this is just an Unreal Tournament style ladder featuring botmatches. When Condition Zero came out, it was seen as outdated. It released two years too late, and the very same year as Valve's own Counter Strike Source. As a result it isn't often talked about when compared to the other games. Since you do get it by default when buying 1.6 it's interesting to play for curiosity's sake, but you'll likely find more players for 1.6 or Source.

												Rank: 7.5/10Recommendation(s): Be a hardcore Counter-Strike fan, understand the old 1.6 mechanics, and play a little bit of Half-Life.Major Theme: Hidden treasure for CS players.Bought at Price: $100 (for Valve Complete Pack)Single player Counter-Strike was always an interesting concept to throw around. So much in fact, a small studio completed it.A quick reminder, this game was designed around Half Life. Linear gameplay in a compact space should be expected. This doesn't mean its bad - plenty of single player games are linear - it just takes time to understand if you haven't played Half Life. Level layouts and item interaction are not going to be what you are used to. Is the game perfect? No, and no game is. Due to the for mentioned old game design theories, certain pathways and mechanics will seem odd. Getting players to do a 180, and come back the way they came can be confusing.I've always been a Counter-Strike fan. There's no denying that. If you are well, you will have a blast with this title (and the Deleted Scenes). This title brings you back to the roots of CS, which allows for a neat experience. Would you play it again and again because of that? Probably not, because I completed the game in 4 hours and that felt like it was enough. I can only really see someone playing this if they are using an old machine with poor internet connection.Being an old engine, AI isn't very good either. The way around that is to place environmental hazards everywhere such as trip mines. Because of this, it feels more like Half Life then Counter-Strike.To wrap this up, if you are a CS player, you are missing something by not playing this. If you aren't, go on in life, there's nothing demanding here for you to play.

												Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is basically 'just' a slightly improved version of Counter-Strike 1.6.If you happen to be unfamiliar with the CS games series, the concept of the idea is simple.Players play against eachother in online matches, choosing to play either a terrorist or a counter terrorist. The team that completes their objective or eliminates the opposing team wins.Counter-Strike is a fairly old game, built on the Half-Life engine, that became extremely popular years ago and is one of the best known shooter games (series) ever made, alongside eg. Unreal Tournament, Doom, Call of Duty and other such classics. And thanks to a large community, there is a huge amount of custom content available for these games. As long as you have some people to play with, it's hard to get bored in the world of Counter-Strike. And Condition Zero is no exception to this.What most people familiar with the series can tell you is that while CZ is a decent game, it is highly underrated compared to both older and newer installments. Why is this? Well there may be several reasons, but the easiest way to put it is this: it's the middle child of CS games.CS purists will prefer to play the original Counter-Strike, versions 1.5 and 1.6. And the newer games draw a big crowd because they're flashier and fancier. Since Condition Zero is situated in between the older 1.6 and Counter-Strike: Source (which started using the new Source engine), it doesn't get much of the attention it deserves, in my opinion. However, I can tell you that it is definitely a game worth playing if you're into slightly older shooting games.--------------------More information...-=Gameplay=-Q: How is it played?A: After joining a server, you have four options. You can join one of two teams, you can let the game decide for you which team you'll join or you can spectate the game, basically existing as a ghost, watching others play. You can play as a counter-terrorist operative or as a terrorist. The moment you spawn (when a new round starts, or within seconds of a round starting) you're able to open a menu that allows you to buy weapons, protection and various equipment. If the round has not yet started, you are unable to move. If you picked a team seconds after the round started, you will instantly be able to move. Everyone spawns with a basic pistol and a little bit of money. Once you're able to move, your goal is to move out of the spawn area and attempt to complete any of your objectives to earn more money and to win the round. When the round is over, everyone respawns in the same area as last round and the game is repeated. If you died, you'll start over with your gear, otherwise you keep what you had before. You will keep playing rounds until the server changes to a different map (level), usually after 20 minutes. There are a couple of standard game types, determined not by server options but by the type of map that is being played. The three main types are bomb defusal, hostage rescue and assassination. There are other types, but those are only featured in custom maps. Completing just ONE of the listed objectives will win a team the round and earn additional money for all of it's members.*Bomb defusal-Terrorists must plant a bomb in one of two possible bomb sites and make sure it explodes. (the team still wins if the bomb explodes while all it's members are dead)-Terrorists must kill all counter-terrorists.-Counter-terrorists have to kill all terrorists.-Counter-terrorists must defuse the bomb if it is planted. (the team still wins if all CT players are killed after the bomb has been defused)*Hostage rescue-Terrorists must stay alive and keep the counter-terrorists from rescuing all living hostages.-Terrorists have to kill all the counter-terrorists.-Counter-terrorists have to rescue all the living hostages.-Counter-terrorists have to kill all the terrorists.*Assassination-Terrorists must keep the VIP from the rescue zone while staying alive themselves.-Terrorists have to kill the VIP.-Counter-terrorists have to kill all the terrorists.-Counter-terrorists have to get the VIP player (picked at random) to the rescue zone within a specific time limit.-=Experience=-CZ is an old game. It runs on an old engine. It looks, feels and sounds old. Quite simply, if you can't stand anything but HD graphics, realistic water effects, decent ragdoll physics and other such things, this is not the game for you. That said, there's enough to keep it interesting. Weapons all sound and behave differently and it takes practice to get good with each (type). The maps are diverse enough in types of environment. It's worth mentioning that in a game like this, the maps are relatively small, forcing players into confrontation to keep the game going at a decent pace. Because the action is usually fast and intense, you will usually be too distracted to really notice what your surroundings sound or look like. For some interesting experiences, try a few custom maps! Made by members of the community, you'll find the craziest levels. Themed ones, maps based on popular films or tv series and just insane maps that seem to be all over the place. Shake things up by customising your game and trying out new things.-=Technical, controls, etc.=-Again, CZ is a fairly old game. As long as you can get the game started, you're not going to have issues with this. It's pretty stable and even if you do suffer a bug or error, you will easily find a solution for it through Google, thanks to the large amount of players who have played this and other CS/HL games over the years.It's extremely small compared to modern games and will take up very little space, even if you start adding custom content to it and customising it further. For anyone with a normal internet connection you can download this game very quickly.Controls are what you're used to in PC shooters. Pretty intuitive and unsurprising. Thankfully, if there's anything that is not working how you want it to, you can change it. Controls can be changed in the options menu and if there's anything not listed in there, you can always find a way to fix it by using the developers console. This may sound complicated if you're a casual PC user/gamer, but again, the community has made sure that there's enough information for you to figure things out without spending a lot of time doing research and basically missing out on actually playing and enjoying the game.Besides regular user controls, there are also enough options and commands by default for server owners (you, if you're hosting a game) to keep control of the match. These can be expanded upon greatly by installing an administrative modification on your game (server) and again, there's enough information for anyone with limited computer knowledge to succeed in this endeavour.Pro's:-Basically an improved Counter-Strike 1.6-Extremely and easily customisable with a lot of custom content available-Easy to learn, hard to master-Features working bots (not brilliant ones in gameplay, though) and the game can "learn" custom maps and make waypoint files for the CZ bots automatically. They work in multiplayer too-Comes with Deleted Scenes, separate game on the same engine that has you playing a proper SP campaign, going across the world to stop terrorist activity in scripted missions.Cons:-Highly underrated and not well known, will not have as much players as other CS games (best played with friends)-Somewhat pricey, unless you're planning on playing it a lot, despite the content available and given with just the game itself------------------------Visit our steam review group page:http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thedairyreviewReviews of games with titles starting with C, and reviews/translations of thisgame (review) by other group members in this thread: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thedairyreview/discussions/0/537405286660678835/

												Holy cow.I'm not really sure how to start this review because I started off with the game being a crappy and basically I had boughten a basically different modeled CS-1.6, lets get down to it?Multiplayer:I didn't get to play too much of this, mainly because there are not too many servers with players, I didn't get to play a few skrim matches though, fun stuff, basically 1.6 (I believe 1.5 was out when this game was available) I don't have too much to talk about here, maps are somewhat different from the original texture wise, there are a few added items like a shield w/ sidearm.Single player:Mainly the reasons why I was interested in this was because of talk of a campaign, when you buy the game, you will find two games in your library, Counter strike condition zero and counter strike condition zero 'Deleted scenes'. Huh, deleted scenes, does not sound that interesting in a game without a story, sounds like something a goldsrc modder would use, open up the regular game to come to a familiar titlepage, when you open up the single player, you are only basically taken to what operations we get in csgo, killing boats for challenges... No story, no different maps, same deal with increasing difficulty, there are plenty of these missions because each difficulty you can select has missions of their own. This was very disappointing and was not worth the $2 price tag, I groaned to myself and probably played five missions before giving up. It was the silliest idea ever. Looking at the games screenshots, there looked like there would at least be  some characters and an okay plot! But sadly what we were given was this "Bot killer simulation 1997". I was greatly disappointed and would have been bothered even more if I had bought this on CD format. Untill. The deleted scenes, who would want to go through that? Well I mean I would, I like to see beta content or removed items and such and that's all I was expecting. Most people are not into that, but I installed that puppy anyways, on the title you are given the option to go to a map screen and start a new game. What I saw five hours that night was one of the best games I have experienced in awhile. WE were actually given a story! Well not really, you were basically pulled into a quick briefing and pulled into chaos, my eyes were glued to the screen. Honestly it felt like I was playing a half life game with realistic environment for its time, wait a minute. What's that say on the wikia for CS condition zero? The game had three development teams? The deleted scenes were made by gearbox?!?!? No freaking wonder the missions were awesome, I have poured five hours into the game and I'm not even half way done, there had to be at least 20 missions all taking place in different environments, one moment you are American in an middle eastern city underseige, the next you are shooting your own comrades in an russian mission plant. Literally, this game (deleted scenes) was amazing and I feel that valve really should had reconsidered gearboxes version of the game.

												Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is the singleplayer addition to the timeless classic: Counter-Strike. The game adds a singleplayer campaign, bots, and graphical polish. While the game itself is very similar to the original Counter-Strike it adds many needed features that the first game lacked. For starters the new graphical polish that the developers added (I think there were something like 4 total devs) makes the game much more believeable and more fun to play. I felt the the developers really took the time to make sure the weapons were as close to real as possible. Because of this the game feels much more tactical than the first. In my personal opinion, this is the most tactical CS game you will find (when I say that I am excluding CS:GO). As for the bots they could've used a bit more work. From todays standards the bots are everything but smart. They often have trouble deciding whether they want to climb a ladder or not and frequentely stare at the wall hoping something exciting will happen. While these bugs are excusable for the age of the title, they do detract from the game. The singleplayer campaign is good and fun to play at times. If you are confused as to what to expect on the singleplayer campaign picture Half-Life but in the Counter-Strike world. Basically if Valve wanted to make CS a singleplayer game they probably would have done it similarly to how it was done in this campaign. It can be fun and actually quite exciting but anything far from challenging. The most challenge you will get out of the campaign is a big enemy with lots of armor and a machine gun.If you are a beginner looking for a introduction to the world of Counter-Strike, this is the way to go. The bots are a perfect difficulty for any new player and the game maintains the feel of the original Counter Strike. Overall Rating: 8/10For my full Counter-Strike review please click on this link: http://steamcommunity.com/id/RYNOMAN/recommended/10/

												Not a whole lot offered here that you can't get from 1.6. Condition Zero creates a whole bunch of scenarios on the already-established maps and game assets, such as getting a certain number of kills during a match or rescuing all hostages. Condition Zero adds a strategic element to the classic Counter-Strike formula by having you pick your computer-controlled squadmates, each with their own levels of skill. You start with some rather mediocre backup, but as you progress in the game, you gain access to more skilled teammates. Balancing your team out and finding players that have their own strengths and can fill in your gaps makes the bots feel more useful. If single-player is your gig when it comes to Counter-Strike, this is a good expansion. However, if you're already deep into 1.6 or you only play online, then this isn't for you.

												(Purchasing this game comes with Counter-Strike 1.6. It's a good deal now, but back in 2004, I doubt many would pay 40 dollars for *just* Condition Zero.)Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is the one Counter-Strike game everyone seems to never talk about. Passing four development teams (Rogue Entertainment - Gearbox Software - Ritual Entertainment - Turtle Rock Studios) and taking four years to complete because of this, this game barely made it out of development hell, and was not well received.This game was going to be more than it currently is, although some things did get in it, such as the Galil, the FAMAS and the Tactical Shield. Don't forget that the idea for a second LMG (M60 - the Negev in CS:GO is close to Gearbox's planned iteration for the M60 stat-wise too), the Grenade section in the Buy Menu, and Molotov Cocktails from CS:GO all originated in Condition Zero.While we will never get to experience the "true" Condition Zero, let's have a look at what eventually got released.Bots: The first Counter-Strike game to feature bots (on PC - Counter-Strike: Xbox was actually the first). They aren't the best, but they play well. Gearbox's version was basically going to have an advanced PODBot, as Markus Klinge was given access to the engine. While this was tested in a beta back in 2003, these bots did not make it to the final version of the game, Turtle Rock Studios' did. Personally, I wish that beta was uploaded somewhere, I'd love to test out the "enhanced" PODBots. (P.S: PODBot works on Condition Zero, so if you'd like those instead; http://podbotmm.bots-united.com/main_pb_page/index.htm)_cz maps: While Condition Zero was going to have new, original maps, those got scrapped in favour of "_cz" maps, which are graphical improvements of the Counter-Strike 1.6 versions. Some new maps do appear in Condition Zero, but the number of them does not reach the one that was going to be in other iterations of the game.Detail Textures: These were developed for Counter-Strike: Xbox, but they were later included in Condition Zero. While these did "update" the look of the game, when compared to other Valve titles which were to release a couple of months later (Half-Life 2/Counter-Strike: Source), these were nothing. Tour of Duty: A very simplified edition of Gearbox's campaign. Involves simple tasks, such as "Kill 4 enemies with [weapon]". There are six Tours of Duty in this game mode and each one consists of three different maps. You aren't alone in these missions however, as you can select up to five (bot) teammates to help you. The bots are divided in to five groups by cost; cost 1, cost 2, cost 3, cost 4, and cost 5 - with the cost being that of "Reputation Points".Deleted Scenes: Ritual Entertainment's campaign, with a few edits. The AI is a bit wonky, but the campaign is fully playable. Features factions that were only seen on Counter-Strike: Xbox, such as the Akunin. (this comes with any purchase of Condition Zero, despite it being "another" game in your library)Mod Support: While this appears in all Counter-Strike games (albeit limited in CS:GO), it's still worth mentioning, as many games don't have it.Dedicated Servers: Same as mod support, but still worth mentioning, especially if you aren't a fan of matchmaking.______________________________________________________________Conclusion: Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a good game, but it could have been much more. I'd recommend it if you'd enjoyed the old (GoldSource) Counter-Strike games, especially since it comes with Counter-Strike 1.6, which is loved by many.

												So, as it seems, CS:CZ is suppose to be a singleplayer game, along with traditional multiplayer mode almost identical to one found in the previous CS instalment, the infamous 1.6. As a player who actually likes playing against bots in online games, such as Counter-Strike (any), Team Fortress 2, FoF, Quake Live, Quake 3 and Quake 3: Team Arena, the whole "singleplayer element" found in CS:CZ is really, really bad in my humble opinion.The gameplay is just like your traditional Counter-Strike but with predifined number of bots and "tasks" instead. The player is given several tasks which MUST be accomplished in order to pass the mission. Unfortunately, majority of these tasks are absolutely what the player SHOULDN'T be doing in a regular CS match. Here are some examples:1. Kill x players2. Kill x players with a specific gun3. Kill x players with a specific gun and survive the round4. Win below x seconds5. Rescue x/all hostagesSo, here's my explanation to the following points respectively:1. Barely any progresss will be made if player's playstyle won't be shifted from cooperative towards tryhardish, with the former being much more welcome in online games. That means, in CS:CZ campaign the player must play aggressively, lone-wolfing, making him prone to dying. Of course, the player may remain cooperative but it will very likely result in a rather unwelcome prolonging of the mission.2. In order to perform well, players should always use weapons they feel comfortable with/high tier weapons, however in this case the player MUST use a specific weapon (usually a fitting one for the map though). Sure, game forces us to try out different guns but in reality the players usually stick to Deagles, AWPs and M4/AK47 for the most of the time anyways. Perhaps that's the task, but still a crappy one, considering players have their most favorite and hated guns, which will never be chosen in an online game anyway.3. Same as above but this time with an opportunity to actually fail the task, forcing the player to be stuck with whatever gun he/she has to stick with for even longer until he/she finally manages to score required amount of frags and also survive the round.4. Another tryhard gameplay promotion. Frag opponents in shortest time possible, meaning, the player must rush B like a ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥ in order to pass the mission. At least it is somewhat challenging at times but again highly discouraged in traditional CS matches.5. The absolute worst of all tasks, since AI controlled hostages can easily get stuck, yet the task will be only ticked off when all of the hostages are rescued. Here's a number of things that can easily prevent player from accomplishing this task:a. Hostage gets stuck and it is no longer reachable (like jumping from a balcony/roof but the hostage doesn't follow). Even if reachable, it's extremely tedious to go back and it also increases chances of encountering an opponent, which can make player's ordeal completely null and void.b. Player manages to get to the hostages, takes them with him/her but bots suddenly frag the very last terro, triggering the win-by-elimination victory.c. hostages get in the way during gunfight, potentially making player stuck, giving terro an opportunity to score a frag and obviously preventing player from finishing this task in this very round. The loss might have an impact on the next round, reducing the chance of accomplishing the task even further.Summary:CS:CZ is a lazy attempt at CS singleplayer mode, full of solutions that are plain wrong and boring. Better stick to a regular game with bots and play as you wish. It could have been much better if it would have taken Half-Life's approach. Instead we have a game. barely different from any of the other CS games but instead with bots and boring, forced tasks. Tedious. That's all that can be said about the campaign. As a singleplayer game I do not recommend it. As a multiplayer game, you better off stick to CS 1.6 instead.

												I remember being given this game on disk by my uncle. It was a great feeling. The game itself was renowned and reading the reviews that were illustrated on the front of the packaging reassured me that this wasn't going to fail me. At first, I didn't play very much of it due to PC complications; after that I then started to play again. I began with the mission, I thought they were great and wished they were brought out to the later games like Source which I love dearly, sadly I was brought down. The missions, in my opinion, were a great addition to Condition Zero especially when you would rage quit multiplayer being hunted down by pros. The missions offered great customization on what teammates you were going to be battling with. Once chosen your teammates you were given a map and then it was left up to you and your teammates to either defuse the bomb or to rescue the hostages. Condition Zero was my first Counter-Strike, people regard CS 1.6 as the original and better game and I have to disagree. Condition Zero in my opinion offered good hitboxes along with fairly accurate registration, apart from defusing bombs haha.

												This is what happens when you have 3 cooks in the kitchen and take too long to get a game out. Compared to Half-Life 2 and Counter-Strike: Source, which both came out in the same year as this game (2004), Condition Zero offers practically nothing. The game was so bad during development that Valve even reverted its "gold" status and changed developers on the project 3 times. The result is that very few ideas feel consistent and connected. Single-Player experience? You just get a bunch of bot matches with arbitrary and unimaginative restrictions and goals to complete missions that are not connected in any way (there isn't even any pretend story). The nicest word I can use for the sense of progression is "limited". Also, when you finish the game, there's just... nothing. Multi-player experience? This game plays exactly like Counter-Strike 1.6, but partitions the players instead of just offering the campaign as an expansion (similar to Diablo II and Diablo II: LoD, which also came out around the same time). There are some exclusive maps, but I failed to see how any of them were an improvement to their CS 1.6 counterparts. Even if the maps were enough of an incentive, it was a pretty low effort endeavor for someone to copy-paste them into the CS 1.6 workshop. This means that you essentially had 2 versions of CS going on at one time, except one of them costed extra so people just stuck with 1.6 instead lol.Graphics? They look like hot garbage compared to the other games from Valve that came out at the same time (Half-Life 2 and CS: Source). The game looks like it was made in 1998.I got this as part of the Counter-Strike complete package during a Steam Sale, and it felt like an incredible chore to finish. There is a video from a recent CS:GO major talking about the history of Counter-Strike, and they mention how "Source is almost forgotten in CS history". Funny how they comment on that while actually omitting CS:CZ from CS history. Honestly, this game is an embarassment.

												I bought 1.6 and I noticed "Condition Zero" and "Condition Zero Deleted Scenes" popped up in my library.  That's a plus, it comes for free with the original counter-strike.Condition Zero is amazing.  It's the Counter-Strike gameplay we all expect, but with a teambuilding menu and a campaign that bears similarities to Unreal Tournament 2004.  Across all the different maps, you'll be fighting the terrorists with your co-op bots, all of which have custom statistics, weapons and stats for Skill, Bravery, and Co-op.  The AI is competent and even unforgiving, minus the annoying standoffs between T's and a riot shielding bot, and the game remains a lot of fun as you have a 'tour' of each map with multiple side-objectives and a round counter.  If you can win three rounds and be ahead by two, and complete your objectives, you move onto the next round.  Trying to balance out easy victories versus, say, completing a round in 75 seconds or getting three tactical shield kills, is surprisingly difficult at times and gives the game a lot of replay value as each difficulty has a new set of objectives (don't even bother with Expert).Now, let's talk about CZ Deleted Scenes.  I've always wondered if Valve ever considered making a Half-Life style campaign for Counter-Strike.  It seems like such an excellent idea... and this seems to be a direct message to me saying "Been there, Done that."  That's right, this is a campaign, complete with events and mission-specific objectives.  In Counter-Strike.  That's where the praise ends, becuase Deleted Scenes is atrocious.  Don't get your hopes up like I did, it's one big steaming turd of broken hitboxes, amazingly horrible voice acting, and OCCASIONALLY showing a small amount of promise as a good game before more turds go into the fan.--These two games along with 1.6 knock GO out of the park.  If you want a Counter-Strike game for both online and offline, look no further than the CS 1.6 + CZ bundle.  Probably some of the greatest $10 you'll ever spend.  Also, there's no chance of an MP shutdown, since Valve holds the servers up with Steamworks to this day-- not that it would shut down, 1.6 is 20,000 concurrent players strong at all times.EDIT: Okay, maybe 30,000 50,000 people... not bad for a game from the 90's.

r 17, 2014
												Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is the first official sequel to mod Counter-Strike, released in retail in 2004. It was pretty much same Counter-Strike on same engine and minimal changes when it comes to multiplayer experience, but it had more to often to solo players, with addition of bots and "Deleted Scenes" pack of single-player missions.Now, for multiplayer community... Is as good as ever. While it's not on the level of Counter-Strike 1.6, you will still be able to find few almost-full servers, whetever it's yet another De_Dust2 map or some server that actually rotates maps. Just more smaller tighter community. BUT it's kinda way too high-skilled by now for newbies to be able to enter in easily.So, when it comes to the main, expected, multiplayer part of the game, it didn't recieve many changes. Explosive grenades are stronger. Hostages are a bit more realistical. The end.Oh, and you will ntoice that graphics got a small boost, as far as HL1 engine goes ("GldSrc"). Models got more detail to them. Few tweaks here and there. Maps are much interesting as far as graphical design goes. If you are going to play de_dust2 non-stop then better do it at the less bland one.And yes, I don't really like Counter-Strike realistical gameplay much here either.Now, for single-player, you finally get some bots to play with. Which are less frustating for new people than online play and helps to hone aiming skills as well better. Though, while they navigate through default maps quite nicely, they don't always make best decision. As a protip, always send them a voice command to stick together, team. They also try not to steal your fun of defusing bomb, waiting for commander to do it, even if said commander is in opposite end of map. Yes, it's a flaw.And like Quake 3 Arena and UT, CZ single player consist of repeated matches with bots, as you will progress through trio of maps, being able to pick less and less stupid teammates over time, always being on side of Counter-Terrorists. And on each map, you have to have more than 2 wins over score of Terrorist team and have to complete each of three objectives, which go like "rescue <x> hostages", "kill <x> amount of Terrorists yourself", "finish some round in <x> time" and "kill <x> terrorists with <y> weapon".  So, fun for a while, but more of "just so something was there".And now for Deleted Scenes. This is what Counter-Strike: Condition Zero was supposed to be at some point, a full-blown single-player campaign. It was "cancelled" once Valve saw magazines giving it low ratings to preview, just to have it put along as bonus into final game. All just to get low ratings once again due to being "more of same". Deleted Scenes had 12 missions in retail release, with Steam version adding 6 more that you can select anytime from World Map.Now, Deleted Scene is a mix of good and bad. The excellent level design and repetive core gameplay.First, good things. Level design is quite good one. You will have to take control of unnamed heroes of counter-terrorist operations all over the world, with missions having great variety, with enough lenght to keep you playing, having to stop terrorists from taking over nuke in snowy part of Russia, defending yourself in Arabain town or fighting your way through the jungles. Seriously, some of the missions just have a bit of that scripted hollywood love that would make them worthy of being in Call of Duty and alikes, quite epic! Levels themselves are also build with knowledge of pacing and a bit of exploration, albeit linear.And it really tries to push GldSrc engine! In order to make it look like it's capable of more than expected, developers made a lot of animations of death for terrorists as well as destruction animations. Hell, I was amazed to see a stack of boxes getting squeezed by a door in the third mission, it's all quite joy to look at even if it's scripted. And well, it does hurt occasionally when it comes to enemies deaths. Like, when you shot with pistol at melee enemy into knee and he suddenly teleported half-meter away to the door, swirled and fell toward the door, just to get it open.But core gameplay of Counter-Strike doesn't translate well at all into linear levels of single-player. What you bassicly will do, is to shoot few bullets into heads, while taking some hitscan bullets back. Repeat it on every enemy. Until the end of the game. It really is repetive and boring. Weapons don't matter much, all of them are good enough for bursting enemy again and again. Grenades aren't given often and flashbang don't seem to be as useful as in multiplayer. Smoke grenade is more offensive there though, making enemies cough instead sometimes. There is little enemy variety as well, you just got whatever hitscan stupid enemy, stationary snipers with laser, whatever melee enemy that rushes you and terrorist with freaking bazooka that is pain to avoid too! So, burst headshot, and burst headshot, repeat repeat repeat.It also finally get to have some music there. For once. So, something definitely good.Counter-Strike Condition Zero is better offer than Counter-Strike 1.6 and has more value for solo players, but it's still not good enough to get me much interested in such twitchy realistical shooter. I still wouldn't recommend new people, especially with newer CS titles out there, only those who already play Counter-Strike should check out this one.

												This game is all about the mission and the offline campaign that was created with it, called the "Condition Zero: Deleted Scenes". It was way easier than 1.6, headshots and spray kills happens way easier than in 1.6, and whereas some spam points has been removed in the old maps (and in the added CZ maps), it doesn't really change the layout all that much. It's still the same game - just easier, imo. I don't recommend it, since the campaign is dull and boring, gameplay answers to 1.6, just easier, as previously mentioned, and lastly, the "Call of Duty" offline bot campaign is so boring and repetitive, you might want to just beat expert, never to come back. It's that terrible. Buy 1.6 instead if you want the game in it's entirety, because CZ, while Source added some new elements and better graphics, is just a blatant copy with extra features thrown in there, for people who doesn't care.
